verses.text: The word of the LORD came to me, saying:
verses.comment: As typical in Ezekiel, God initiates communication. The phrase emphasizes that true prophecy comes from God, not human imagination.

verses.text: "Son of man, prophesy against the prophets of Israel who prophesy, and say to those who prophesy out of their own hearts, 'Hear the word of the LORD!'"
verses.comment: God instructs Ezekiel to confront false prophets who speak from their own thoughts rather than divine inspiration. See Jeremiah 23:16 for a similar rebuke.

verses.text: Thus says the Lord GOD: Woe to the foolish prophets who follow their own spirit and have seen nothing!
verses.comment: God condemns prophets who lack true vision and rely on themselves. This models discernment between true and false prophecy—a principle affirmed throughout Scripture.

verses.text: Your prophets, O Israel, are like jackals among ruins.
verses.comment: Jackals among ruins suggests opportunism in times of national crisis. Spiritually, it indicates corruption—a theme repeated in both Old and New Testaments.

verses.text: You have not gone up into the breaches or built a wall around the house of Israel, so that it might stand in battle on the day of the LORD.
verses.comment: True spiritual leaders are called to intercede and protect the community. The allusion to standing in the breach hints at mediation, which foreshadows the mediatory work seen in the New Testament.

verses.text: They have seen false visions and lying divinations. They say, 'Declares the LORD,' even though the LORD did not send them; and yet they expect Him to fulfill their word.
verses.comment: This rebuke is severe; claiming divine authority falsely is a grave offense, as reinforced in Jeremiah and Acts (Acts 5:1–11). The motif warns against presumption in spiritual matters.

verses.text: Have you not seen a false vision and spoken a lying divination, when you said, 'Declares the LORD,' even though I have not spoken?
verses.comment: God again exposes deception. True prophecy requires authentic divine commission—a standard later clarified by Christ’s own claims to speak with the Father’s authority (John 5:19).

verses.text: Therefore thus says the Lord GOD: Because you have spoken falsehood and seen lies, therefore I am against you, declares the Lord GOD.
verses.comment: Divine opposition to deceitful authorities is integral to biblical justice. God actively resists those misleading His people.

verses.text: My hand will be against the prophets who see false visions and give lying divinations. They shall not be in the council of my people, nor be registered in the house of Israel, nor enter the land of Israel. Then you shall know that I am the Lord GOD.
verses.comment: Exclusion from God’s people and the land points to spiritual consequences. The book of Revelation echoes this, affirming true inclusion in the heavenly city to those faithful to God.

verses.text: Because, yes, they have led my people astray, saying 'Peace,' when there is no peace. And when anyone builds a wall, they coat it with whitewash.
verses.comment: ‘Whitewashed walls’ symbolize superficial spirituality. Jesus later employs this imagery to warn against hypocrisy, connecting Old Testament typology to His teaching ministry.

verses.text: Say to those who coat it with whitewash that it will fall. There will be a torrential rain, and you, O hailstones, will fall; and a stormy wind will break it.
verses.comment: The coming judgment mirrors Jesus’ parable of the houses built on sand (Matthew 7:27)—only true foundations withstand the storms. This alludes to Christ as the true foundation (1 Cor. 3:11).

verses.text: When the wall is fallen, will you not be asked, 'Where is the coating with which you smeared it?'
verses.comment: False assurances are exposed by crisis. The focus on external appearances echoes Jesus’ correction of the Pharisees.

verses.text: Therefore thus says the Lord GOD: I will make a stormy wind break out in my wrath, and in my anger torrential rain will fall, and hailstones in destructive fury.
verses.comment: God’s judgment depicted as natural disasters communicates His active response to spiritual corruption.

verses.text: I will break down the wall that you have coated with whitewash, and level it to the ground so that its foundation is laid bare. And when it falls, you will perish under it; then you shall know that I am the LORD.
verses.comment: Collapse reveals flawed foundations. This symbolizes how spiritual teachings must be built upon revealed truth, foreshadowing the importance of sure doctrine preserved through apostolic tradition.

verses.text: Thus I will spend my wrath upon the wall and upon those who coat it with whitewash, and I will say to you, ‘The wall is no more, nor those who coated it.’
verses.comment: The eradication of false leadership is necessary for restoration. The image of complete removal aligns with God’s holy character and desire for a pure community.

verses.text: They are the prophets of Israel who prophesied about Jerusalem and saw visions of peace for her, when there was no peace, declares the Lord GOD.
verses.comment: Again, false security is condemned. This points toward the prophetic role of testifying to true peace—a theme fulfilled by Christ, who brings eternal peace.

verses.text: "Now, son of man, set your face against the daughters of your people, who prophesy out of their own hearts, and prophesy against them,"
verses.comment: Both men and women can engage in deception. Spiritual discernment is critical for all members of the faith community.

verses.text: "Thus says the Lord GOD: Woe to the women who sew magic bands on all wrists, and who make veils for the heads of persons of every stature, in order to hunt souls! Will you hunt down souls among my people and preserve your own lives?"
verses.comment: The reference to magic bands and veils suggests practices foreign to proper worship. This distinction between true worship and superstition is important, hinting at the spiritual warfare theme in Ephesians 6:12.

verses.text: "You have profaned me among my people for handfuls of barley and for pieces of bread, killing souls who should not die and keeping alive souls who should not live, by your lying to my people who listen to lies."
verses.comment: Selling spiritual influence for food trivializes God’s holiness. This precedent establishes that spiritual authority is not for personal gain—a theme revisited in Acts 8:20 with Simon Magus.

verses.text: Therefore thus says the Lord GOD: Behold, I am against your magic bands, with which you hunt souls like birds, and I will tear them from your arms; and I will let the souls you hunt go free, the souls like birds.
verses.comment: Images of souls as birds escaping traps point to deliverance. There is a spiritual dimension—freedom is possible only through God’s intervention, prefigured in the ministry of Christ.

verses.text: I will tear off your veils and deliver my people from your hands, and they shall no longer be prey in your hands. Then you shall know that I am the LORD.
verses.comment: God’s saving power is evident in rescuing His people from deception and bondage—foreshadowing Christ’s work of liberation.

verses.text: Because you have discouraged the righteous with lies, when I did not grieve him, and you have strengthened the wicked, that he should not turn from his wicked way to save his life,
verses.comment: Uplifting the wicked and discouraging the righteous reverses God’s justice. This echoes later teachings that the Church protects the vulnerable and challenges the wicked, showing a spiritual and hierarchical ordering.

verses.text: Therefore you shall no longer see false visions or practice divination. I will rescue my people from your hand, and you shall know that I am the LORD."
verses.comment: God promises to deliver His people from false spiritual influences. This points toward the ongoing need for genuine authority and true teaching, fulfilled in Christ’s ministry and continuing evident in the apostolic tradition throughout church history.
